awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Political Connections and Firm Behavior
awd_abstract_narration:
GENERAL SUMMARY

This project examines the effect of political connections on firm behavior. Both theory and previous research suggest that political connections confer greater profitability in such environments, but the extent to which such connections have real (as opposed to merely distributional) effects is an open question. To explore this question, the project utilizes a firm-level panel dataset that spans two periods of profound and largely unanticipated disruptions to political connections (the Orange Revolution in 2004 and the Euromaidan Revolution in 2013 and 2014. Contemporary Ukraine is the case of interest. Ukraine provides an environment in which there are weak political institutions and substantial oligarchic control of the economy. The results of this study will provide evidence on the channels through which political connections affect firms and will shed light on the real, as opposed to monetary, consequences of these connections.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This project examines the effect of political connections on firm behavior and productivity, with an empirical focus on contemporary Ukraine. The research utilizes a firm-level panel dataset with many unusual variables (not just profitability, but also productivity, employment, wages, investment, R&D and IT investment, and energy inputs), supplemented with new data on oligarchic ownership. The data span two periods of profound and largely unanticipated disruptions to political connections the Orange Revolution in 2004 and the Euromaidan Revolution in 2013-14. Using new methods developed for this work and leveraging a natural experiment, the analysis will examine not only the direct effect of these shocks on connected firms, but also the indirect effects of spillovers on competitors (which may feed back to political outcomes) and on industry dynamics and productivity. The results of this study will provide evidence on the channels through which political connections affect firms and shed light on the consequences of these connections.

por.por_cntn:
Political connections provide various benefits to firm owners, including the protection of property from expropriation and arbitrary taxation -- a necessary condition for investment and growth. Absent these connections, owners may turn to other means of securing their property. A common but underexplored method is to "obfuscate" ownership through frontmen and related individuals, shell companies, and offshore firms. With beneficial ownership obscured behind complicated ownership chains, expropriation through the courts may be difficult. Involvement of foreign entities may further complicate legal assault. Offshore ownership can also facilitate the transfer abroad of profits and liquid assets, including to low-tax jurisdictions 

We explore this idea in a study of the behavior of "oligarchs" in Ukraine -- a country of generally poor protection of property rights -- around the time of the Orange Revolution in 2004. Prior to 2004, Ukrainian oligarchs were generally divided into two camps: "Blue," who supported the incumbent president and his chosen successor, Viktor Yanukovych, and "Orange," who supported the opposition candidate Viktor Yushchenko. Combining information from investigative journalists with rich data on legal ownership ties, we identify the ownership chains of Blue and Orange oligarchs before and after the Orange Revolution. Our primary interest is the relationship between political connections (stronger for Blue before the Orange Revolution, stronger for Orange after) and various measures of obfuscation of ownership.

The included figure illustrates the relationships revealed in the data. In 2004, just prior to the Orange Revolution, Orange oligarch Petro Poroshenko owned a vast network of confectionary and other firms. With comparatively weak ties to those in power, Poroshenko hid ownership behind frontmen and shell companies, as reflected in his absence from the formal ownership chains of firms he controlled. Offshore entities are also quite common in Poroshenko's ownership network. In contrast, Blue oligarch Rinat Akhmetov's System Capital Management was established to be comparatively transparent, with relatively short ownership chains that typically led to Akhmetov himself. Able to rely upon those in power for protection from predation, Akhmetov avoided the opportunity and direct costs of obfuscating ownership behind complicated arrangements. 

This negative relationship between connections and obfuscation is broadly evident in the data. In particular, we observe the same pattern if we exploit the variation in political connections induced by Ukraine’s political-economic geography: more Blue firms in the eastern regions that supported Yanukovych in 2004, and relatively more Orange firms in areas that supported Yushchenko. Notably, we also observe a reversal of behavior following the Orange Revolution, as the value of Blue connections declined sharply with Yushchenko’s election victory. After 2004, previously connected oligarchs such as Akhmetov added foreign owners, including offshore vehicles, to obscure and protect their ownership.

In an environment of generally poor protection of property rights, political connections and obfuscation of ownership can both secure property from predation. Our results clearly demonstrate the substitutability of these two mechanisms in postcommunist Ukraine around the time of the Orange Revolution. An interesting question for future research is whether we would observe similar patterns in countries with stronger properety rights and more frequent political turnover.
